author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Averts All-Out War With Hezbollah, but Its Regional Conflicts Grind On
description: Relief that an eruption of violence across the border between Israel and Lebanon has been contained is tempered by a lack of progress in ending the fighting in Gaza.
content: After weeks of foreboding, an all-out war between Israel and Hezbollah has been averted, at least for now, as both sides returned on Monday to more contained confrontations along the Israel-Lebanon border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Inflation Is Fading, Statistically and Politically
description: The cost of living may not be the G.O.P.’s, um, trump card.
content: Last week was full of speeches. Most of those that attracted national attention were at the Democratic National Convention, culminating in Vice President Kamala Harris’s big moment on Thursday. But there was another important speech on Friday: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s talk at the Fed’s annual shindig in Jackson Hole, Wyo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Alabama High School Football Player Dies After Sustaining Head Injury
description: Caden Tellier, a quarterback, was critically injured after being tackled in the third quarter of a game on Friday night, school officials in Selma said. He died on Saturday.
content: A high school quarterback in Selma, Ala., died after sustaining a critical brain injury during his team’s first game of the season on Friday night, school officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $825,000 Homes in California
description: A midcentury retreat in Idyllwild, a two-bedroom condominium in Playa del Rey and a two-bedroom townhouse in Campbell.
content: This home, known as Idyllhouse, is a popular vacation rental within a 10-minute drive of hiking trails in the nearby mountains. It has been carefully restored and updated by the sellers, who added a new kitchen and primary bathroom, but retained classic midcentury elements like the red cedar paneling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: For His Second Trip to Space, Billionaire Has Grander, Riskier Aspirations
description: Jared Isaacman is leading three other privately trained astronauts on a SpaceX vehicle for Polaris Dawn, a mission that will include a daring spacewalk.
content: Three years ago, a billionaire entrepreneur named Jared Isaacman made a groundbreaking trip to space. That spaceflight, which Mr. Isaacman called Inspiration4, was the first to orbit the Earth without a professional astronaut aboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Trump and Harris Embody a Stark Partisan Divide on Fighting Poverty
description: The two presidential candidates can both point to records of pushing poverty rates down, but their approaches could hardly be more different.
content: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Will A.I. Ruin the Planet or Save the Planet?
description: It’s a notorious energy hog. But artificial intelligence can also foster innovation and discovery, and it could speed the global transition to cleaner power.
content: The global experiment in artificial intelligence is just beginning. But the spending frenzy by big tech companies for building and leasing of data centers, the engine rooms for A.I., is well underway. They poured an estimated $105 billion last year into these vast, power-hungry facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri and Ali Watkins
title: 1 Tourist Is Dead and 1 Injured After Ice Canyon Collapses in Iceland
description: Rescuers on Monday called off a search for what they initially believed were two other trapped tourists after it became clear that all the visitors were accounted for.
content: Rescuers in Iceland on Monday called off the search of a deadly ice canyon collapse after they determined that, contrary to initial reports, there were no other tourists trapped beneath the debris, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Kamala Harris Has Left the Building
description: The convention may be over, but there’s still a lot to discuss.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I can’t wait to hear your impression of Kamala Harris’s big Chicago speech. Tell, tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Colorado Republicans Vote Out Party Chair Following Anti-Gay Posts
description: State Republicans accused Dave Williams, who was ousted in a landslide vote, of dividing the party with “hateful narratives,” most recently against the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: Colorado Republicans have voted to remove their party’s chairman amid mounting internal criticism of his leadership, including over recent posts that attacked the L.G.B.T.Q. community and accusations that he had fueled divisions within the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,165
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 27, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz
title: How a Federal Court in New Orleans Is Driving the Conservative Agenda
description: Today, the U.S. Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals is an outlier. But a Trump victory in November could transform it into the standard-bearer of MAGA-era jurisprudence.
content: The Supreme Court term that ended this summer delivered a number of big wins for traditional conservative causes. The court made it easier to challenge federal regulations. It made it harder to prosecute former presidents. And it delivered another decision that expanded the rights of gun enthusiasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Maggie Astor
title: Harris and Trump Squabble Over Debate Rules as ABC Matchup Looms
description: The former president derided the network and questioned why he would participate, while the vice president called for each candidate’s microphone to be left on for the entirety of the Sept. 10 event.
content: At the weigh-in before a big bout, prizefighters often taunt their opponents in an effort to try to psych them out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: After Israel’s military and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah fired back and forth over the weekend in one of the largest cross-border barrages since the war in Gaza began, both sides quickly claimed victories of sorts. By yesterday morning, the two sides were employing the language of containment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Harris and Trump Squabbled Over Debate Rules
description: Also, Russia attacked Ukraine’s energy infrastructure. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Donald Trump said today that he was still “thinking about” whether he should participate in a Sept. 10 debate with Kamala Harris on ABC News, threatening again to pull out of the only debate that both candidates have agreed to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Fox Hunters in the U.K. Want Protected Status Under Discrimination Law
description: A lobbying group is preparing a bid to define hunting with animals as a protected belief. Many experts have questions.
content: English fox hunters have tried, for years, to push back against a nearly 20-year-old ban on their beloved sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Captain of Sunken Yacht Under Investigation in Deaths on Ship
description: The investigation does not necessarily imply that formal charges will follow against the captain, James Cutfield.
content: Italian authorities have opened a formal investigation into the actions of James Cutfield, the captain of the superyacht that sank last Monday off the coast of Sicily, killing seven of the 22 people on board, including British tech billionaire Mike Lynch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Telegram Turmoil Threatens Dominant Chronicle of the War in Ukraine
description: The detention of Telegram’s founder has highlighted the messaging app’s outsize status in Europe’s deadliest war since World War II.
content: The detention of Pavel Durov, the founder of the Telegram messaging app, in Paris on Saturday has raised questions about the future of a platform that has come to define the public perception of Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood and Maya King
title: Democrats Look to End the Electability Question
description: The party is battling a squishy, often self-reinforcing concept about the perceived ability to win.
content: This year, Angela Alsobrooks, the county executive of Prince George’s County, Md., and a Democrat, sought support for her U.S. Senate bid from an elected official she had known for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Raphael and Kristian Thacker
title: Doctors Saved Her Life. She Didn’t Want Them To.
description: When her “do not resuscitate” order was ignored, Marie Cooper found herself in a painful situation she had hoped to avoid.
content: Marie Cooper led her life according to her Christian faith. She baked pies for her neighbors in northern West Virginia, and said grace before even a bite of food. She watched Jimmy Swaggart, a televangelist preacher — a little too loudly, in her daughter Sherry Uphold’s opinion. And she always said that at the end of her life, she did not want to be resuscitated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: A Trial Asks: If Grocery Rivals Merge, Do Workers Suffer?
description: As Kroger seeks to acquire Albertsons, federal regulators argue that the biggest supermarket combination in history will hurt not only consumers, but workers as well.
content: Back in 2015, Leonard De Monte was feeling settled. At 31, he had health insurance and was making a union wage at the Vons grocery store in Woodland Hills, Calif., where he had worked for more than a decade. A familiar face in the bakery section, he knew dozens of frequent shoppers’ orders by heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy
title: Harris Has the Momentum. But Trump Has the Edge on What Matters Most.
description: With early voting only weeks away, the race is still a close one.
content: Every Monday morning on The Point, we kick off the week with a tipsheet on the latest in the presidential campaign. Here’s what we’re looking at this week:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
title: How Telegram’s Founder Went From Russia’s Mark Zuckerberg to Wanted Man
description: Pavel Durov’s anti-establishment streak helped him create one of the world’s biggest online platforms, which emphasizes free speech. It also put a target on his back.
content: More than a decade ago, when Russia pushed Pavel Durov to shut down the pages of opposition politicians on a Facebook-like site he had created, the tech entrepreneur responded online by posting a cheeky picture of a hoodie-wearing dog with its tongue out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Uber Fined $324 Million by Dutch Watchdog Over Driver Data Protection
description: The authorities in the Netherlands said the ride-hailing company had violated European data protection laws when it sent sensitive information to the United States.
content: Uber faces a fine of 290 million euros, or more than $324 million, over a violation of European Union rules that protect data privacy, a Dutch agency said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Sean Combs Fights Lawsuit by Music Producer Alleging Sexual Misconduct
description: The hip-hop mogul’s lawyers are seeking the dismissal of a suit from Rodney Jones Jr., arguing it is baseless and “replete with far-fetched tales of misconduct.”
content: Lawyers for Sean Combs filed court papers on Monday seeking the dismissal of a civil suit by a music producer who accused Mr. Combs of making unwanted sexual contact, arguing that the lawsuit was baseless and “replete with far-fetched tales of misconduct.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michal Leibowitz
title: Gossiping Is Fun. It’s Natural. And These People Won’t Do It.
description: Gossip is a universal feature of human culture. It’s also the target of passionate, widespread censure.
content: In its most recent survey on the topic, the polling giant YouGov found that half of Americans admit to having “spread a piece of gossip.” YouGov did not report that the other half of Americans are filthy little liars, but it probably could have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Afyare A. Elmi and Yusuf Hassan
title: The Coming War Nobody Is Talking About
description: East Africa is on the cusp of conflict.
content: Trouble has horns to hold but not tails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Lowry
title: Trump Can Win on Character
description: Presidential races are won and lost on character as much as the issues, and often the issues are proxies for character.
content: With the defenestration of Joe Biden and the ascent of Kamala Harris, conventional wisdom has gone from asking, “How can Donald Trump lose?” to “How can he win?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: China to Hold Live-Fire Drills Near War-Torn Myanmar
description: Beijing likely wants to signal to Myanmar’s junta leaders that they should return to peace talks and de-escalate the conflict, analysts said.
content: China will hold live-fire military drills near its border with Myanmar starting on Tuesday, fortifying its boundaries with a southern neighbor that has been engulfed in a civil war for more than three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: Wave of Attacks Rattles a Restive Province in Pakistan
description: At least 38 people have been killed in several assaults across Baluchistan Province since Sunday in what appears to be part of a campaign by armed separatists in the region.
content: The violence began with blasts that ripped through a military camp in Pakistan’s Baluchistan Province late Sunday night, killing at least one soldier. Around the same time, armed men stormed into at least four police stations in the province, spraying bullets at officers and setting police vehicles on fire, local officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rolf Potts
title: What’s the Best Way to Explore Kenya? Join a Local Hiking Club.
description: The author sought an authentic experience, and found it in Lets Drift, “an exuberant Kenyan-centered enterprise” of people living in and near Nairobi.
content: By the time we reached the third waterfall on the Kahunira trail, my wife, Kiki, and I had been walking through the forested backcountry of Kiambu County, Kenya, for nearly three hours. Along the way, we had tasted sweet lady finger bananas in the market town of Githunguri, sipped a sour Kikuyu home brew called muratina proffered by laborers at a rural gravel quarry and made a heart-pounding shortcut across rust-flecked irrigation pipes that traversed a steep gorge fringed with tea plantations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Latino Civil Rights Group Demands Inquiry Into Texas Voter Fraud Raids
description: The organization said many of those targeted by the raids, conducted by a unit created by the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, were Democratic leaders and election volunteers.
content: A Latino civil rights group is asking the Department of Justice to open an investigation into a series of raids conducted on Latino voting activists and political operatives as part of a sprawling voter fraud inquiry by the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and James C. McKinley Jr
title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Will Continue in Cairo, Officials Say
description: Four days of high-level meetings failed to achieve a breakthrough, but people briefed on the talks said discussions on technical issues would take place in the coming days.
content: A day after Israel and Hezbollah traded major cross-border attacks but swiftly moved to contain a bigger war, the focus in the Middle East returned on Monday to the effort to achieve a cease-fire in Gaza, where Israel’s 10-month-long war with Hamas is at the heart of rising regional tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Will Impose 100% Tariffs on Chinese Electric Vehicles
description: The new tariffs announced by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will match levies imposed by President Biden and could further strain relations between Canada and China.
content: In a significant escalation of trade tensions between Western countries and China, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Monday that Canada would impose 100 percent tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, joining the United States and the European Union in protecting domestic car production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Fare Evasion Surges on N.Y.C. Buses, Where 48% of Riders Fail to Pay
description: New York’s bus system has one of the worst fare evasion problems of any major city in the world. The issue is more pronounced on buses than in the subway.
content: Every weekday in New York City, close to one million bus riders — roughly one out of every two passengers — board without paying. The skipped fares are a crucial and growing loss of revenue for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is under severe financial pressure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jim Tankersley, Diana Nguyen, Nina Feldman, Sydney Harper, Rikki Novetsky, Clare Toeniskoetter, Devon Taylor, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Brad Fisher and Chris Wood
title: Trump vs. Harris on the Economy
description: A Times economic policy reporter breaks down the candidates’ plans on the issue.
content: As the 2024 presidential race enters the homestretch, former President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris are putting economic policy at the center of their pitches to voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 443
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level and if you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Sabrina Carpenter Is Gloriously Sly and Merciless
description: The pop singer and songwriter’s new album, “Short n’ Sweet,” lives up to her ubiquitous summer hits.
content: In Sabrina Carpenter’s songs, young romance is all sexy fun and games — until it’s not. “Short n’ Sweet,” her sixth full-length album, is a smart, funny, cheerfully merciless catalog of bad boyfriend behavior and the deceptions and rationalizations that enable it. Carpenter mostly smiles and winks her way through songs that recognize the irrational power of lust, but deftly twist the knife on cheaters and hypocrites. “No one’s more amazing at turning loving into hatred,” she warns in “Good Graces.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spark Bird
description: Stories about birds — the hearts they sway, the havoc they wreak, the lives they change.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: A Fire in East London Recalls Deadly Grenfell Cladding Scandal
description: More than 80 people were evacuated in the early hours of Monday from a building that had used similar insulation.
content: More than 80 people had to be evacuated after a major fire broke out in east London early Monday, fire officials said. The blaze brought back painful memories of the Grenfell Tower fire that killed 72 people in the city in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Eric Butler, 49, Dies; Promoted ‘Restorative Justice’ for Young People
description: As a counselor, he embraced an alternative to “zero tolerance” disciplinary policies that are disproportionately meted out to Black students.
content: Eric Butler, an anti-violence counselor with a gift for winning the trust of emotionally closed-off teenagers, who worked with students, school districts and prosecutors’ offices to divert young people from being sucked into the criminal justice system, died on Aug. 4 at his home in New Orleans. He was 49.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: 2 Men Charged With Damaging Ancient Rock Formation at Lake Mead
description: In a video from April, two men appear to be pushing large red rocks — estimated to be over 100 million years old — over the edge of a cliff at Lake Mead National Recreation Area in Nevada.
content: Two men were indicted last week on charges that they damaged an ancient rock formation at Lake Mead National Recreation Area in Nevada in April, federal prosecutors said. A video appeared to show the men toppling some of the rocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke and OK McCausland
title: The Stuff They Strut on the Jellicle Catwalk
description: From the first solo to the euphoric final bows, dance is essential to the world-building of “Cats: The Jellicle Ball.” Watch four standout dancers from the reinvented classic.
content: Before anyone steps onto the catwalk in “Cats: The Jellicle Ball,” the wildly popular reimagining of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Cats” at the Perelman Performing Arts Center, a dancer’s silhouette appears at the back of the stage, darting across a row of windows. At first, his movement recalls the limber ballet-jazz of the original 1982 Broadway production, accented with tricks like a split leap and a back walkover. He has two little ears, a tail. He could be prowling on a rooftop at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Dangerous Heat Returns to Central and Eastern U.S. This Week
description: High heat and humidity could make it feel like 115 degrees Fahrenheit in parts of the country this week, forecasters warned.
content: Forecasters warned that “dangerous heat and humidity” will spread across the central and eastern United States this week, threatening to break records for high temperatures and ending a spell of fall-like weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden, Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
title: Telegram Founder’s Arrest Part of Broad Investigation, French Prosecutors Say
description: A case was opened last month to investigate child pornography, drug sales, fraud and other criminal activities on the platform. The app’s founder, Pavel Durov, was detained over the weekend near Paris.
content: Prosecutors in France said on Monday that Pavel Durov, the entrepreneur who runs the Telegram messaging platform, had been arrested in connection with an investigation opened last month into criminal activity on the app and a lack of cooperation with law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: Why Nippon Steel’s $15 Billion Takeover of U.S. Steel Is in Peril
description: The proposed merger of Japanese and American industrial giants, which proponents say would benefit both countries, is ensnared by political and labor opposition.
content: When U.S. Steel put itself up for sale in 2023, executives at Nippon Steel in Tokyo saw an opportunity: Buying the American steel maker could help it offset anemic demand in its home country and strengthen its hand in a global business dominated by China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Rashid Johnson Will Have Career Survey at Guggenheim in 2025
description: A major exhibition by the acclaimed artist will fill Frank Lloyd Wright’s rotunda with plants and artwork. Johnson stepped down from the Guggenheim’s board last year.
content: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum’s landmark 1959 building, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, has always presented singular opportunities for living artists to engage with its sculptural spiraling ramp and central oculus illuminated by a domed skylight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: Disabled Troops Used to Have to Leave the Military. Now Some Compete for Gold.
description: The Warrior Games have become a symbol of the military’s changing perceptions about who is fit to serve. Some of the athletes make it to the Paralympics, which start this week in Paris.
content: Master Sgt. Ivan Morera isn’t used to being in last place. He’s a Green Beret. A relentless competitor. But at the 2024 Warrior Games, with his prosthetic hand hooked into a rowing machine, he was trailing the pack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno
title: In a First, a Chinese Military Plane Breaches Japan’s Territorial Airspace
description: The territorial violation by China is the latest in a series of events amplifying tensions between Beijing and Japan.
content: A Chinese military surveillance plane breached Japanese airspace off the country’s southwestern coast on Monday, marking what Japan’s defense ministry described as the first known incursion by China’s military into its territorial airspace.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 26, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 26, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Kamala Harris Needs to Do to Take On China
description: Washington cannot win “the competition for the 21st century” against Beijing by itself.
content: The United States needs a strategy for dealing with China as an economic and national security threat, and Donald Trump’s blustery “America First” approach ain’t it. Kamala Harris has a better shot because of her belief in strengthening alliances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Kroger’s Nearly $25 Billion Merger Is Bad for Shoppers, F.T.C. Says
description: The Federal Trade Commission, which is trying to block Kroger’s plan to acquire Albertsons, said in court that the merger of grocery giants would also hurt workers’ pay and benefits.
content: A trial that could determine whether the two largest supermarket chains in the United States can merge opened in Portland, Ore., on Monday, pitting the grocery giant Kroger against regulators who argue that its takeover of Albertsons would eliminate competition at the expense of consumers and workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: menial
description: This word has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word menial has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 7 in “I Didn’t Truly Know My Mother Until I Cooked With Her” by Priya Krishna:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Mark Mazzetti, Hamed Aleaziz and Ian Stewart
title: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Airstrikes, and U.S. Border Crossings Drop
description: Plus, an ambitious, risky private space mission.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Rudy Franchi, Who Put Movies at the Center of a Technicolor Life, Dies at 85
description: He brought French classics to New York, published a film magazine, worked as a Hollywood publicist and, as seen on “Antiques Roadshow,” thrived selling vintage film posters and other ephemera.
content: Rudy Franchi, who during a kaleidoscopic life brought French films to New York City, indulged in trysts with Hollywood stars as a publicist, operated one of the country’s largest vintage movie poster businesses and appraised ephemera — most memorably, a lunch menu from the Titanic — on the PBS program “Antiques Roadshow,” died on Aug. 6 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Why California Is Considering Banning Food Dyes in Schools
description: Concerns about their risks have been swirling for years. Here’s what the science suggests.
content: For decades, researchers have been trying to answer a hotly contested question: Do the synthetic dyes used to add vibrant colors to foods like certain breakfast cereals, candies, snacks and baked goods cause behavioral issues in children?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Post Malone Returns to No. 1 With His Country Debut, ‘F-1 Trillion’
description: The shape-shifting pop songwriter’s new album debuts atop the Billboard 200, and Chappell Roan’s “Midwest Princess” holds at No. 2.
content: Post Malone, the face-tattooed singer and songwriter who emerged a decade ago with a rock-meets-folk-meets-rap style that caught fire on streaming services, opens at No. 1 on the latest Billboard album chart with “F-1 Trillion,” which repositions the star in a country context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Sid Eudy, Wrestler Known as ‘Sid Vicious’ and ‘Sycho Sid,’ Dies at 63
description: The 6-foot-9 wrestling champion faced off against some of the industry’s biggest names, including Shawn Michaels and Hulk Hogan.
content: Sid Eudy, a professional wrestler known as Sid Justice, Sid Vicious and Sycho Sid, who rose to fame in the 1990s and won multiple championships, died on Monday. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: A 95-Square-Foot Caravan Inspired by Roald Dahl
description: The multimedia artist Yto Barrada has turned the tiny wagon in her Moroccan garden into a guesthouse.
content: The 53-year-old multimedia artist Yto Barrada grew up in a blue two-story house in a verdant Tangier neighborhood that overlooks the Strait of Gibraltar. About a decade ago, the Moroccan French artist, who also lives in New York City, transformed part of the family compound — including several small structures, as well as an expansive botanical garden that provides the flora she uses to make natural dyes — into what she recently named the Mothership, an experimental arts center where she offers textile and other workshops and hosts artists’ residencies. One of its newest additions, in another small garden up the path from the main street, is a 95-square-foot single-room pinewood caravan, a 50th-birthday gift to Barrada from her husband, the American filmmaker and actor Sean Gullette. “It’s my favorite present ever,” she says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Dam Collapse Devastates Communities in Eastern Sudan
description: The Arba’at dam fell apart after days of heavy rain, killing villagers and flooding communities.
content: A dam that collapsed in Sudan near the Red Sea on Sunday flooded surrounding communities and caused an unknown number of deaths and injuries, local and international officials said. The disaster heaped additional misery on a country where millions are already suffering from war and famine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Now an Acclaimed Restaurateur, He Long Concealed a Secret
description: Arjav Ezekiel rose through the restaurant ranks becoming a sommelier and opening Birdie’s in Austin, Texas. Few knew of his past as an undocumented immigrant.
content: From the outside, Arjav Ezekiel appears to be living the dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Brooch That Diana Vreeland Kept on Her Night Stand, Reimagined
description: A new Tiffany & Co. jewelry collection mines the archive of the designer Jean Schlumberger.
content: Born into a textile manufacturing dynasty in German-held Alsace in 1907, Jean Schlumberger resisted his parents’ attempts to steer him into banking or the family business and eventually made his way to Paris in the 1930s. There he began working under the couturier Lucien Lelong (who would later become Christian Dior’s mentor). Known to frequent the stalls of the Marché aux Puces, Schlumberger would collect antiques: hand-painted relics, Victorian serpents and multicolored glass objects. By 1936, he was transforming porcelain flowers from old funeral wreaths into fantastical brooches, which were worn by his circle of artist friends, including Jean Cocteau and Christian Bérard. Schlumberger’s whimsical creations also caught the eye of the Italian fashion designer Elsa Schiaparelli, who asked him to create buttons shaped like starfish and plumed hats for her winter 1937 collection. That December, his designs were featured in Harper’s Bazaar, including “a gilded chain with jeweled tassels,” “flying fish earrings” and “a brooch made of roller-skating feet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Museum to Part With Cranach Portrait Sold as Owner Fled the Nazis
description: The Allentown Art Museum agreed to sell the work, by Lucas Cranach the Elder and his workshop, to settle a restitution claim by a Jewish family, which will share in the proceeds.
content: A Pennsylvania museum is relinquishing a valuable 16th-century portrait attributed to Lucas Cranach the Elder and his workshop after reaching a settlement with descendants of a German Jewish couple who fled the Nazis before World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Is Your Water Bottle Really Made From Recycled Plastic?
description: A green accounting method called “mass balance” certifies that something was manufactured with recycled plastic — just not necessarily much of the bottle making the claim.
content: The plastic CamelBak bottles displayed in a Target in East Hanover, N.J., offer a promise to ecologically conscious buyers. On the front of each is a bright blue sticker with the words “Tritan Renew made with 50% recycled material.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: My Bookshelf, Myself
description: To walk past the bookcases in our family’s house is to make a different study of the history of time.
content: My husband, Haywood, reached retirement age this summer, but instead of actually retiring, he decided to stay on and teach part time. I work from home, alone in a silent house, and I am thrilled to have more time with the person I like best in all the world. The only downside was his stuff. When it’s time to give up his classroom, what does a veteran English teacher do with 37 years’ worth of posters and three-ring binders and author photos and various bringing-literature-to-life aids? What does he do with all the books?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In This Fleet, Funny Novel, a Writer Makes Art and Sells Out in Hollywood
description: In “Colored Television,” by Danzy Senna, a struggling writer in a mixed-race family is seduced by the taste of luxury that comes with house-sitting.
content: Danzy Senna’s “Colored Television” is among the first major novels of 2024’s truncated fall book season — truncated because few publishers want to release a novel anywhere near the blast zone of the November election — but it feels more like a summer blockbuster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Benefits of Shorter Campaigns
description: Presidential campaigns are marathons. Not this year.
content: Presidential campaigns are marathons: They start years before Election Day and proceed through door-knocking, living room meetings, candidate debates, newspaper interviews, leafleting, primaries, caucuses and nominating conventions. It’s not unusual, just a few months after a new president is sworn in, to see a contender stake out a state that holds an early primary or caucus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Love Them or Hate Them, This Couple Reign in Russian Literature
description: For Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky, translating together extended naturally from their relationship as husband and wife. Now, it is their life’s work.
content: The first time Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky translated a Russian novel together, it felt as though another man had joined their marriage: Dostoyevsky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Assassination Task Force Visits Butler as Right Wing Promises a ‘Parallel’ Inquiry
description: As members of the newly formed bipartisan task force investigating the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump began their work, some hard-right Republicans were already warning of a cover-up.
content: Members of the newly formed House task force on the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump took one of their first investigative steps on Monday, traveling to the site of the shooting in Butler, Pa., to scrutinize the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: From War’s Carnage Springs a Renaissance of Ukrainian Poetry
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 26, 2024.
content: “Ten years ago, it would have been unimaginable for a poet to fill a stadium.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Raphael
title: What to Know About Getting a DNR Order
description: A “do not resuscitate” order can help you communicate your priorities for medical treatment. Here’s what to consider — and how to increase the chances that your wishes are upheld.
content: A “do not resuscitate” order instructs medical workers in and outside of a hospital not to restart your heart if it stops. It prohibits CPR and associated resuscitative measures, including electrical shocks to the heart, intubation, ventilation and certain medications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Wang and Mike Ives
title: Fighting Sexual Temptation? Play Badminton, Hong Kong Tells Teenagers.
description: Top officials in the Chinese territory have defended new sex education guidance that critics call regressive. Young people are amused.
content: A 15-year-old girl and her boyfriend are studying alone together on a hot summer day when she removes her jacket and clings to his shoulder. What should he do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juleanna Glover
title: Republican Donors, Do You Know Where Your Money Goes?
description: We know the rules on political giving are broken, but so are the rules on spending.
content: We long ago blew past any meaningful controls on political giving in American elections. Now we should focus on the rules governing political spending, which are in equally terrible shape. For that we can blame the Trump campaign and the federal government’s feeble enforcement efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Choose Your Own Meatball Adventure
description: Play with the protein, spices, herbs and aromatics in this meatball recipe to get the exact combination you want for tonight’s dinner.
content: I almost never follow recipes, at least not exactly. I like to add a pinch of this and a spoonful of that, guided by what’s in my pantry and what I’m hungry for. This is why I find it almost physically impossible to make the same thing twice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What We Can Learn From Tim Walz and His Son, Gus
description: Parents of neurodivergent children praise a guest essay by Tina Brown. Also: Is Trump funny? RFK Jr.’s endorsement of Trump; antitrust law.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Russia Launches a Large-Scale Attack
description: Plus, badminton instead of sex.
content: Russia launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a broad swath of Ukraine yesterday. President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the assault as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Deadly Landslide Strikes Ketchikan, Alaska
description: The disaster killed one person and injured three in the town. Researchers said heavy rains preceding the disaster may have played a role.
content: A violent landslide has raced down a forested hillside in Ketchikan, Alaska, killing one person and injuring three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: No Evidence That Maduro Won, a Top Venezuelan Election Official Says
description: In an interview with The New York Times, an electoral council official expressed grave doubts about claims to victory by the authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro.
content: One of Venezuela’s top election officials, in a declaration sure to jolt the crisis-weary nation, said in an interview that he had no proof that Venezuela’s authoritarian president won last month’s election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia Pounds Ukraine With ‘One of the Largest Strikes’ of the War
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned an assault of more than 200 missiles and drones that ranged from Kyiv to Odesa to Ukraine’s West. Energy infrastructure was again a target.
content: Moscow launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a wide swath of Ukraine on Monday, damaging energy facilities and sending residents of Kyiv into basements and subways to seek shelter. President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the assault as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Wei-Haas
title: Dismantling the Ship That Drilled for the Ocean’s Deepest Secrets
description: The JOIDES Resolution, which for decades was key to advancing the understanding of the Earth and its innards, concluded what could be its final scientific expedition.
content: A global cataclysm is portrayed in black and white in the sediments off the southeastern coast of the United States. Deep below the seafloor, chalky muds evince an ancient ocean flourishing with life. But a stark black layer cuts through the pale grains, marking the moment 66 million years ago when a six-mile wide asteroid slammed into Earth and our planet was never the same. The impact, known as the Chicxulub event, set off dramatic climate swings that sent 75 percent of Earth’s species — including all non-avian dinosaurs — spiraling toward extinction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Polio Vaccines Arrive in Gaza, but Distributing Them Is the Next Challenge
description: UNICEF is pushing for a pause in the fighting to allow health workers to get two doses to every child, after Gaza recorded its first polio case in 25 years.
content: More than 1.2 million doses of the polio vaccine arrived in Gaza on Monday, in preparation for an expansive effort to inoculate more than 640,000 Palestinian children and curb a potential outbreak, the United Nations, Israel and health authorities in Gaza said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Another New Leader for Indianapolis Museum Roiled by Racism Outcry
description: Le Monte Booker will be the institution’s third leader in four years. The previous president and chief executive left last year after just over a year on the job.
content: The Indianapolis Museum of Art is getting its third leader in four years as it continues to deal with the fallout from a racially insensitive job posting that led to its longtime leader’s departure in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Forbes
title: Humanitarians Are Dying. Why Doesn’t the World Care?
description: The president of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies makes an impassioned plea for protecting humanitarian aid workers.
content: In February I met a man. Three hours later, he was dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Jill Stein Will Remain on the Ballot in Wisconsin After Court Order
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court denied a Democratic challenge to the Green Party candidate’s ballot access in the state.
content: Jill Stein, the presidential candidate for the Green Party, will remain on the ballot in Wisconsin, the state’s Supreme Court said, after the court declared a Democratic technical challenge to her ballot access moot on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is It Better to Be Over- or Underdressed?
description: A reader seeks guidance on striking the right balance between casual and formal attire at events without a defined dress code.
content: This is like “Hamlet,” the S.N.L. version. You can just imagine a host wandering around a set crying, “to overdress or underdress, that is the question?” as they beat their breast and rend their doublet. In truth, there are two camps here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Hits Harris Over ‘Humiliation’ in Military’s Afghan Exit
description: Courting military votes, Donald Trump visited Arlington National Cemetery to observe the anniversary of a deadly Kabul bombing and then spoke at a National Guard group’s conference.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump wrapped himself in military imagery on Monday, attacking the Biden administration over its withdrawal from Afghanistan. Observing the third anniversary of a deadly suicide bombing in Kabul, the Afghan capital, he visited Arlington National Cemetery, then later spoke in Detroit to a gathering of National Guard members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Parisians Are Choosing Bikes Over Cars. Will New Yorkers Do That, Too?
description: The transformation of cycling access in Paris over the past few years may have lessons for New York and its car-clogged streets.
content: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: A New Generation of Club Kids Is Born. They’re Younger Than You Think.
description: In New York, dance spots for tots and techno heads alike are thriving, with veteran D.J.s, oversize headphones and zero “Baby Shark.”
content: At a recent dance party in Brooklyn, Berk Sawyer, wearing Nike high-tops and a white bodysuit covered in city icons like pigeons and a hot-dog stand, bopped his head to the heavy bass. Occasionally, he bounced so hard he tumbled to the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman
title: The Cyclone Suddenly Goes Silent in Coney Island
description: The 97-year-old roller coaster, a New York landmark, was taken out of service temporarily after a crack was detected in its machinery.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. James Barron is on vacation. Today we’ll look at why the Cyclone in Coney Island was taken out of service just before Labor Day weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Appeal Dismissal of Trump Documents Case
description: The special counsel, Jack Smith, argued that Judge Aileen Cannon had erred in throwing out charges against Donald Trump of improperly holding national security secrets after leaving office.
content: Federal prosecutors began their bid to resurrect the moribund classified documents case against former President Donald J. Trump on Monday, telling an appeals court in Atlanta that the trial judge had improperly thrown out the charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Democrats Sue Georgia Election Board, Warning of ‘Chaos’
description: The board recently passed new rules aimed at altering the process for certifying elections. The lawsuit says such changes are illegal.
content: Democrats sued the Georgia state election board on Monday, arguing that measures approved by the board this month seeking to alter the election certification process in the state were illegal and could create chaos on Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Hungry for Clean Energy, Facebook Looks to a New Type of Geothermal
description: As electricity demand from data centers soars, Meta and Google are looking at a novel solution: harnessing clean heat far below Earth’s surface.
content: Big tech companies across the United States are struggling to find enough clean energy to power all the data centers they plan to build.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Three Los Angeles Museums Team Up to Acquire Art
description: The Hammer, LACMA and MOCA are establishing a joint collection, starting off with a gift of 260 works from the collectors Jarl and Pamela Mohn.
content: As cultural institutions are recognizing the potential for pooling resources, the Hammer Museum, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles are establishing a joint collection of contemporary art by Los Angeles artists, to be founded through the acquisition of nearly 300 artworks from the collectors Jarl and Pamela Mohn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: What’s Dining Out Like For a Vegetarian New Yorker? Share Your Experience.
description: The New York Times Food team wants to hear your stories, to help inform our reporting.
content: Eating out in New York has changed drastically in the last several years. It’s now more expensive, more diverse and in theory, more accommodating of dietary restrictions. But even as terms like “plant based” and “vegetable forward” are tossed around, the question remains: Just how vegetarian-friendly are the city’s restaurants?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Gus Walz Brought Out Both the Joy and the Cruelty
description: He deserved the kind of treatment any person does.
content: Gus Walz’s unbridled emotional reaction last week at the Democratic National Convention to the nomination of his father, Gov. Tim Walz, embodied both the humanity that lies beneath the political process and the momentousness of the political process itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: Bridging the Uplifting and the Harrowing in San Francisco
description: Heather Knight, the San Francisco bureau chief for The New York Times, strives to reflect all sides and perspectives of the city.
content: When former President Donald J. Trump said at a news conference this month that he once nearly died in a helicopter ride with Willie Brown, the former mayor of San Francisco, Heather Knight immediately picked up the phone and dialed Mr. Brown.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Isabel Wilkerson Looks Back at ‘The Warmth of Other Suns’
description: The fifth in a series of conversations with authors appearing on our “Best Books of the 21st Century” list.
content: As part of its recent “100 Best Books of the 21st Century” project, The New York Times Book Review is interviewing some of the authors whose books appeared on the list. This week, Isabel Wilkerson joins our host Gilbert Cruz to discuss her 2010 book “The Warmth of Other Suns: The Epic Story of America’s Great Migration.” In his write-up for that project, Dwight Garner called it “the most vital and compulsively readable work of history in recent memory.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Guess These Novels That Originally Got Bad Times Reviews?
description: Some works that went on to become popular literary classics first got mixed or bad reviews. Try this short quiz to see if you recognize the novels as described by their original reviewers in The Times.
content: Some works that went on to become popular literary classics first got mixed or bad reviews. Try this short quiz to see if you recognize the novels as described by their original reviewers in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: The 100 Best Books of the 21st Century: A Printable List
description: Print this version to keep track of what you’ve read and what you’d like to read.
content: Print this version to keep track of what you’ve read and what you’d like to read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia
title: When A.I.’s Output Is a Threat to A.I. Itself
description: As A.I.-generated data becomes harder to detect, it’s increasingly likely to be ingested by future A.I., leading to worse results.
content: As A.I.-generated data becomes harder to detect, it’s increasingly likely to be ingested by future A.I., leading to worse results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Russia Strikes Ukrainian Cities With Missiles and Drones
description: Cities across Ukraine were hit in a widespread attack that also targeted energy infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said.
content: Cities across Ukraine were hit in a widespread attack that also targeted energy infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times
